title: 'World's fattest woman' pictured lying in bed after life-saving weight-loss surgery reduces 79 stone bulk by a fifth
text:
Eman Ahmed in bed after her surgery (Photo: SAIFEE HOSPITAL) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A woman thought to be the world's fattest has undergone life-saving weight-loss surgery. 
Eman Ahmed, 36, was pictured lying in bed after surgeons reduced her 79 stone bulk by almost a fifth (16 stone). 
She had not left her home for 25 years prior to the surgery. 
She was lifted out of her bed by crane and put on a cargo plane for the journey from her Egypt home to India. Doctors aim to reduce her weight by 200 kg this year so she can fit on the operating table (Photo: Barcroft Media) Eman Ahmed seen in her first pictures post surgery to treat her extraordinary weight (Photo: Newslions / SWNS.com) 
One of the world's leading bariatric surgeons had volunteered to treat her after an appeal from her family for help. 
A spokesperson for Mumbai's Saifee Hospital confirmed the surgery had taken place. 
"We are trying to get her fit enough to fly back to Egypt as soon as possible," the hospital said in a statement. 
She had been losing a stone a day leading up to the op after being put on a special 1,200 calorie a day diet. Read More Seventy-eight stone Eman Ahmed was flown from her home in Egypt to India on a specially modified cargo plane to undergo a series of operations to help her lose weight (Photo: Barcroft Media) Read More 'World's heaviest woman' leaves her home for first time in 25 years for life-saving surgery Her family posted a desperate plea online to Egyptian president Abdel Fattah el-Sisi asking for medical assistance (Photo: Newslions / SWNS.com) 
Medics today said in her first five days at the hospital she lost a staggering 66lbs - more than 13lbs a day - after being put on a liquid diet. 
Eman was reportedly born with elephantiasis - a parasitic infection which causes extreme swelling in a person's limbs and arms. 
She has been heavy all her life and by the time she was 11 she was too heavy to walk, and had to crawl to get around. She suffered a cerebral stroke as a child which left her bed-ridden and she piled on the pounds. Like us on Facebook
